chapterDescription: This chapter introduces the fundamental mathematical concept of sets, covering their definitions, representations, types, and operations, which serve as the basis for relations, functions, and probability.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.description: Provides the historical context of Set Theory and its importance in modern mathematics.

content.introduction: The concept of a set serves as a fundamental part of present-day mathematics. Today, this concept is being used in almost every branch of mathematics. Sets are used to define the concepts of relations and functions. The study of geometry, sequences, probability, etc., requires the knowledge of sets.

coreConcepts.explanation: The theory of sets was developed by the German mathematician Georg Cantor (1845-1918). He encountered sets while working on problems on trigonometric series. Before this, mathematics dealt primarily with concrete numbers and geometric shapes. Cantor's work abstracted these into collections of objects, creating a unified language for mathematics.
coreConcepts.example: Cantor defined a set as a collection of definite and distinguishable objects of our perception or thought.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A timeline showing Georg Cantor's life and the publication of his seminal works on Set Theory in the late 19th century.

coreConcepts.explanation: Set theory provides the structural framework for all of mathematics. For instance, in probability, the sample space is a set of all possible outcomes. In geometry, a line is defined as a set of points. Without sets, defining functions—the core of calculus—would be impossible.
coreConcepts.example: In probability, if we toss a coin, the set of outcomes is \{Heads, Tails\}.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A tree diagram connecting 'Set Theory' to branches like 'Probability', 'Calculus', 'Logic', and 'Topology'.

summary: Set theory is the fundamental language of modern mathematics.
Georg Cantor is the father of Set Theory.
Sets are essential for defining relations, functions, probability, and geometry.

quickCheckQuestions.question: Who is considered the developer of set theory?

content.title: Introduction to Set Theory
content.description: A visual journey through the history of Georg Cantor and why sets are the building blocks of logic.

content.title: Check Your Understanding: Intro to Sets
content.description: Test your knowledge on the history and application of sets.

questions.question: Which mathematician is credited with developing the theory of sets?
questions.explanation: Georg Cantor (1845-1918) developed the theory of sets while working on trigonometric series.

questions.question: Set theory is used in the study of Probability.
questions.explanation: Yes, concepts like sample spaces and events in probability are defined using sets.

questions.question: Sets are only used in Algebra.
questions.explanation: Sets are used across geometry, sequences, probability, logic, and calculus.

content.title: Thinking Like a Mathematician
content.description: Apply the concept of collections to real-world scenarios.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the role of sets in Geometry?
options: Sets are used to calculate area only.
Geometric figures like lines and planes are defined as sets of points.
Sets are used to measure angles.
questions.explanation: In modern geometry, all figures are fundamentally collections (sets) of points satisfying specific conditions.

questions.question: Why is it important for a collection to be 'well-defined' to be a set?
questions.explanation: Without a well-defined criteria, membership becomes subjective (e.g., 'best actors'), making mathematical logic impossible.

sections.title: Sets and their Representations
sections.description: Defines what constitutes a set and methods to write them mathematically.

content.introduction: Not every collection of objects is a set. In mathematics, we require precision. This section explores how to distinguish a mathematical set from a general collection and the two standard ways to write them.

coreConcepts.explanation: A set is a **well-defined** collection of objects. 'Well-defined' means that given any object, we can definitely decide whether it belongs to the collection or not. The objects in a set are called elements or members.
coreConcepts.example: The collection of vowels in the English alphabet \{a, e, i, o, u\} is a set. The collection of 'good cricket players' is NOT a set because 'good' is subjective.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A comparison chart showing 'Well-defined' vs 'Not Well-defined' collections.

coreConcepts.explanation: In Roster form, all elements are listed, separated by commas, and enclosed within braces \{ \}. The order of elements is immaterial, and elements are generally not repeated.
coreConcepts.example: The set of even positive integers less than 7 is represented as \{2, 4, 6\}.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Visual showing braces enclosing numbers separated by commas.

coreConcepts.explanation: In Set-builder form, we describe the set by a single common property possessed by all elements. We write \{x : P(x)\}, read as 'the set of all x such that x has property P'.
coreConcepts.example: The set \{a, e, i, o, u\} can be written as \{x : x \text{ is a vowel in the English alphabet}\}.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Annotation of the syntax: Braces, variable x, colon (such that), and the condition.

summary: A set must be well-defined.
Roster form lists elements: \{1, 2, 3\}.
Set-builder form describes properties: \{x : x < 4, x \in \mathbb{N}\}.

quickCheckQuestions.question: Is 'The collection of difficult problems in math' a set?

content.title: Representing Sets
content.description: Learn how to convert between Roster form and Set-builder form with examples.

content.title: Mastering Set Notation
content.description: Test your ability to identify sets and convert notations.

questions.question: Which of the following is a well-defined set?
options: A collection of tall students in a class
A collection of prime numbers less than 10
questions.explanation: Prime numbers less than 10 are strictly {2, 3, 5, 7}. The other options rely on subjective adjectives (beautiful, tall, interesting).

questions.question: In Roster form, the set of letters in the word 'SCHOOL' is written as:
questions.explanation: In sets, repetition of elements is ignored. 'O' is written only once.

questions.question: The set {x : x is a natural number and 3 < x < 4} is an empty set.
questions.explanation: There is no natural number strictly between 3 and 4.

content.title: Converting Set Forms
content.description: Convert between Roster and Set-builder forms.

questions.question: Write the set \{x : x \text{ is an integer and } -3 < x < 7\} in Roster form.
questions.explanation: Strict inequality (<) means -3 and 7 are excluded. Integers include 0. The set is {-2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}.

questions.question: Write the set \{2, 4, 8, 16, 32\} in Set-builder form.
questions.explanation: The elements are powers of 2. $2^1=2, 2^5=32$. Thus, $x=2^n$ where $n$ is a natural number from 1 to 5.

sections.title: The Empty Set
sections.description: Introduces the concept of a set containing no elements.

content.introduction: It might seem strange to talk about a collection with nothing in it, but the concept of zero is crucial in arithmetic, and the concept of the empty set is equally crucial in set theory.

coreConcepts.explanation: A set which does not contain any element is called the empty set, the null set, or the void set. It is denoted by the symbol $\phi$ (phi) or $\{\}$.
coreConcepts.example: Let $A = \{x : 1 < x < 2, x \text{ is a natural number}\}$. Since there is no natural number between 1 and 2, $A$ is an empty set.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: An image of an empty basket labeled 'Empty Set' next to the symbol $\phi$.

coreConcepts.explanation: The set $\{0\}$ is NOT an empty set; it is a set containing one element, which is the number zero. Similarly, $\{\phi\}$ is not an empty set; it is a set containing the empty set as an element.
coreConcepts.example: If $B = \{0\}$, then $n(B) = 1$. If $C = \phi$, then $n(C) = 0$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Visual distinction: A box containing a ball labeled '0' vs an empty box.

summary: The empty set has no elements.
It is denoted by $\phi$ or $\{\}$.

quickCheckQuestions.question: Is the set of even prime numbers greater than 2 an empty set?
quickCheckQuestions.answer: Yes, because 2 is the only even prime number.

content.title: Understanding the Empty Set
content.description: Why we need a set with nothing in it and how to identify it.

content.title: Identifying Null Sets
content.description: Determine if specific descriptions result in an empty set.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the empty set?
questions.explanation: φ is the standard notation. {φ} contains φ, {0} contains 0, and 0 is a number, not a set.

questions.question: The set of odd integers divisible by 2 is an empty set.
questions.explanation: By definition, odd numbers are not divisible by 2. Thus, no such number exists.

content.title: Null Set Analysis
content.description: Solve algebraic conditions to find if sets are empty.

questions.question: Consider $A = \{x : x^2 = 4, x \text{ is odd}\}$. Is A empty?
options: Yes, because the roots of x²=4 are even.
No, because x=2 is in the set.
No, because x=-2 is in the set.
Yes, because x² can never be 4.
questions.explanation: $x^2 = 4$ implies $x = 2$ or $x = -2$. Both are even numbers. The condition requires $x$ to be odd. Thus, no element satisfies both conditions.

questions.question: Solve for set B: $\{x : x \in \mathbb{R}, x^2 + 1 = 0\}$.
questions.explanation: For any real number $x$, $x^2 \geq 0$. Therefore, $x^2 + 1 \geq 1$. It can never be 0. The set is empty.

sections.title: Finite and Infinite Sets
sections.description: Classifies sets based on the countability of their elements.

content.introduction: Sets can describe small collections, like the planets in our solar system, or vast concepts, like the stars in the universe or numbers on a number line.

coreConcepts.explanation: A set which is empty or consists of a definite number of elements is called finite. The number of distinct elements in a finite set $A$ is denoted by $n(A)$ (cardinality).
coreConcepts.example: If $W$ is the set of days of the week, $W$ is finite and $n(W) = 7$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A closed box containing a specific number of dots.

coreConcepts.explanation: A set whose elements cannot be listed by a definite number (i.e., the counting process never ends) is called an infinite set. We often represent these with three dots (ellipsis).
coreConcepts.example: The set of natural numbers $\mathbb{N} = \{1, 2, 3, ...\}$ is infinite.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A number line extending indefinitely with an arrow.

summary: Finite sets have a countable number of elements.
Infinite sets go on forever.
Cardinality $n(A)$ applies to finite sets.

quickCheckQuestions.question: Is the set of animals living on Earth finite or infinite?

content.title: Finite and Infinite Sets
content.description: Examples distinguishing between finite collections and infinite mathematical sets.

content.title: Classifying Sets
content.description: Determine if the following sets are finite or infinite.

questions.question: The set of points on a line segment is:
questions.explanation: Between any two distinct points, there are infinitely many points.

questions.question: The set of prime numbers less than 99 is finite.
questions.explanation: We can count them exactly. The counting process stops at the largest prime before 99.

content.title: Advanced Classification
content.description: Analyze algebraic definitions to determine finiteness.

questions.question: State whether the set $A = \{x : x \in \mathbb{N} \text{ and } (x-1)(x-2) = 0\}$ is finite or infinite.
questions.explanation: Solving $(x-1)(x-2)=0$ gives $x=1$ and $x=2$. Since $x$ must be a natural number, $A = \{1, 2\}$. It has 2 elements, so it is finite.

questions.question: State whether the set $B = \{x : x \in \mathbb{R} \text{ and } 0 < x < 1\}$ is finite or infinite.
questions.explanation: There are infinitely many real numbers between 0 and 1 (e.g., 0.1, 0.01, 0.001...).

sections.title: Equal Sets
sections.description: Explains the criteria for two sets to be considered identical.

microsections.title: When are two sets the same?

content.introduction: In algebra, 5 = 2 + 3. In set theory, we also need a definition for equality. Two sets are equal if they contain exactly the same elements.

coreConcepts.explanation: Two sets A and B are said to be equal if they have exactly the same elements and we write $A = B$. If they are not equal, we write $A \neq B$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Two circles with identical contents, showing equality regardless of arrangement.

coreConcepts.explanation: A set does not change if one or more elements are repeated or listed in a different order. This is key to determining equality.
coreConcepts.example: Let $A = \{1, 2, 3\}$ and $B = \{2, 2, 1, 3, 3\}$. Since every element of A is in B and every element of B is in A, $A = B$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Visual mapping checking elements from Set A to Set B.

summary: $A=B$ if every element of A is in B and vice versa.
Order does not matter.
Repetition does not matter.

quickCheckQuestions.question: Are {a, b} and {b, a, a} equal?

content.title: Equal vs Equivalent Sets
content.description: Explaining the difference between equal sets and sets with the same number of elements.

content.title: Testing Equality
content.description: Identify if pairs of sets are equal.

questions.question: If A = {1, 2} and B = {x : x is a root of x² - 3x + 2 = 0}, then A = B.
questions.explanation: Solving x² - 3x + 2 = 0: (x-1)(x-2)=0 -> x=1, 2. So B={1, 2}. Thus A=B.

questions.question: Set A = {W, O, L, F} and Set B = {F, O, L, L, O, W}. Are they equal?
questions.explanation: Repetition allows 'L' and 'O' to appear twice in B, but the unique elements are F, O, L, W, which matches A.

content.title: Determining Equality
content.description: Solve problems involving set definitions.

questions.question: Find the values of x and y if sets $A = \{2, x\}$ and $B = \{y, 4\}$ are equal.
questions.explanation: If $A=B$, they must have the same elements. 2 must be in B, so $y=2$. 4 must be in A, so $x=4$.

questions.question: Let $X$ be the set of letters in 'ALLOY' and $Y$ be the set of letters in 'LOYAL'. Is $X=Y$?
questions.explanation: $X = \{A, L, O, Y\}$. $Y = \{L, O, Y, A\}$. The distinct elements are identical.

sections.title: Subsets
sections.description: Explores the relationship where one set is contained entirely within another.

content.introduction: Just as a class is part of a school, a set can be part of another set. This relationship is called being a subset.

coreConcepts.explanation: A set $A$ is a subset of a set $B$ if every element of $A$ is also an element of $B$. We write $A \subset B$. If $A$ is not a subset of $B$, we write $A \not\subset B$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Venn diagram showing circle A completely inside circle B.

coreConcepts.explanation: Real numbers define specific subsets called intervals. Open interval $(a, b) = \{x : a < x < b\}$. Closed interval $[a, b] = \{x : a \le x \le b\}$.
coreConcepts.example: $[2, 5]$ includes 2 and 5. $(2, 5)$ excludes them.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Number lines showing filled dots for closed intervals and hollow circles for open intervals.

coreConcepts.explanation: If $A \subset B$ and $A \neq B$, then $A$ is called a proper subset of $B$. The set $B$ is the superset of $A$.
coreConcepts.example: $\{1\} \subset \{1, 2\}$ is a proper subset. $\{1, 2\} \subseteq \{1, 2\}$ is not proper.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Visual comparison of proper vs improper subset.

summary: $A \subset B$ means all elements of A are in B.
Every set is a subset of itself ($A \subset A$).
The empty set is a subset of every set ($\phi \subset A$).

quickCheckQuestions.question: Is {a} a subset of {a, b, c}?

content.title: Subsets and Intervals
content.description: Visualizing subsets and understanding interval notation on the number line.

content.title: Subset Notation and Logic
content.description: Test your grasp of subset symbols and definitions.

questions.question: Which symbol represents 'is a subset of'?
questions.explanation: ⊂ is the subset symbol. ∈ means 'element of'.

questions.question: {a, b} ⊄ {b, c, a}
questions.explanation: {a, b} IS a subset of {b, c, a} because both a and b are in the second set.

questions.question: The interval [3, 4] corresponds to:
questions.explanation: Square brackets [ ] denote a closed interval, meaning inclusive of endpoints (≤).

content.title: Applying Subset Logic
content.description: Determine relationships between sets and intervals.

questions.question: Let $A = \{1, 2, \{3, 4\}, 5\}$. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT?
questions.explanation: {3, 4} is an *element* of A, not a subset. For it to be a subset, the elements 3 and 4 would need to be in A individually, or it should be written as {{3, 4}} ⊂ A.

questions.question: Write the set $\{x : x \in \mathbb{R}, -5 < x \le 7\}$ as an interval.
questions.explanation: Strict inequality at -5 uses '('. Inclusive inequality at 7 uses ']'.

sections.title: Power Set
sections.description: Introduces the set of all subsets of a given set.

content.introduction: If we collect all possible subsets of a set into a new set, we get the Power Set.

coreConcepts.explanation: The collection of all subsets of a set $A$ is called the power set of $A$. It is denoted by $P(A)$. In $P(A)$, every element is a set.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A visual breakdown of breaking a set {a, b} into its components.

coreConcepts.explanation: If a set $A$ has $n(A) = m$ elements, then the number of elements in the power set is $n(P(A)) = 2^m$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A table showing Set Size vs Power Set Size (1->2, 2->4, 3->8).

summary: $P(A)$ contains all subsets of A.
The empty set and the set itself are always in $P(A)$.
Size is $2^m$.

quickCheckQuestions.question: If A has 3 elements, how many elements are in P(A)?

content.title: Mastering Power Sets
content.description: How to list every subset systematically and calculate cardinality.

content.title: Power Set Properties
content.description: Test your ability to calculate power set size.

questions.question: If $A = \phi$, what is $P(A)$?
questions.explanation: The only subset of the empty set is the empty set itself. So P(A) = {φ}. It has $2^0 = 1$ element.

questions.question: If a set has 5 elements, its power set has 32 elements.

content.title: Listing Subsets
content.description: Practice listing elements of power sets.

questions.question: List all elements of the power set of $A = \{x, y, z\}$.
options: {x, y, z, xy, xz, yz, xyz}
questions.explanation: We need all combinations: 0 elements (φ), 1 element ({x}...), 2 elements ({x,y}...), and 3 elements ({x,y,z}). Total 8.

questions.question: If $n(P(A)) = 256$, find $n(A)$.

sections.title: Universal Set
sections.description: Defines the larger set containing all sets under consideration in a specific context.

content.introduction: When we study sets, we usually deal with elements from a particular context. This larger context is the Universal Set.

coreConcepts.explanation: The Universal Set, denoted by $U$, is a set that contains all the elements under consideration for a particular problem. All other sets in the problem are subsets of $U$.
coreConcepts.example: If we are studying the set of integers, the Universal Set $U$ could be the set of Rational numbers $\mathbb{Q}$ or Real numbers $\mathbb{R}$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A large rectangle labeled U containing smaller circles A and B.

summary: U contains all elements in a specific context.
It is usually represented by a rectangle in Venn diagrams.

quickCheckQuestions.question: For the set of right triangles, what is a valid universal set?

content.title: Context Matters: Universal Sets
content.description: Defining the 'Universe' for your math problem.

content.title: Choosing the Universe
content.description: Select appropriate universal sets.

questions.question: Given sets A = {1, 3, 5}, B = {2, 4, 6}, and C = {0, 2, 4, 6, 8}. Which is a valid Universal Set?
questions.explanation: The Universal Set must contain ALL elements from A, B, and C. Option 2 is valid, but Option 4 is also valid (and covers them). Usually, we pick the one that covers all. Note: Option 2 is {0,1,2,3,4,5,6,8}, which covers all elements. Option 4 covers them too. Any superset works.

content.title: Defining Context
content.description: Identify U for geometric and algebraic sets.

questions.question: If $A$ is the set of isosceles triangles and $B$ is the set of equilateral triangles, suggest a Universal Set.
options: Set of all triangles in a plane
questions.explanation: The set of all triangles is the most specific superset that naturally contains both A and B.

sections.title: Venn Diagrams
sections.description: Uses graphical illustrations to visualize sets and relationships between them.

content.introduction: Most relationships between sets can be represented by means of diagrams known as Venn diagrams, named after English logician John Venn.

coreConcepts.explanation: The universal set $U$ is represented by a rectangle. Its subsets are represented by closed curves, usually circles, inside the rectangle.
coreConcepts.example: If $U = \{1, 2, ... 10\}$ and $A = \{2, 4, 6, 8, 10\}$, we draw a circle labeled A inside the rectangle, placing the even numbers inside the circle and odd numbers outside.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A rectangle U with a circle A inside. 2,4,6,8,10 are inside A; 1,3,5,7,9 are outside A but inside U.

coreConcepts.explanation: If $A \subset B$, circle A is drawn entirely inside circle B. If sets intersect, the circles overlap.
coreConcepts.example: For overlapping sets, the shared area represents common elements.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Two overlapping circles labeled A and B.

summary: Rectangle = Universal Set.
Circle = Subset.
Overlap = Intersection.

quickCheckQuestions.question: Where do elements belonging to both A and B go?

content.title: How to Draw Venn Diagrams
content.description: Step-by-step guide to representing sets visually.

content.title: Interpreting Diagrams
content.description: Answer questions based on visual descriptions.

questions.question: In a Venn diagram, if Circle A and Circle B are disjoint (no overlap), what does this imply?
options: A is a subset of B
A and B have no elements in common
questions.explanation: Disjoint circles mean the intersection is empty.

content.title: Visual Logic
content.description: Translate data to diagrams.

questions.question: If $A \subset B$, describe the Venn diagram.
options: Circle A is inside Circle B
Circle B is inside Circle A
questions.explanation: Since all elements of A are in B, the region of A must be entirely contained within B.

sections.title: Operations on Sets
sections.description: Covers mathematical operations performed on sets to form new sets.

content.introduction: Just as addition and multiplication are operations on numbers, Union and Intersection are operations on sets.

coreConcepts.explanation: The union of A and B is the set of all elements which are either in A or in B (or in both). Symbol: $A \cup B = \{x : x \in A \text{ or } x \in B\}$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Venn diagram with both circles A and B fully shaded.

coreConcepts.explanation: The intersection of A and B is the set of elements common to both. Symbol: $A \cap B = \{x : x \in A \text{ and } x \in B\}$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Venn diagram with only the overlapping middle region shaded.

coreConcepts.explanation: The difference $A - B$ is the set of elements belonging to A but NOT to B. $A - B = \{x : x \in A, x \notin B\}$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Venn diagram with Circle A shaded except for the part overlapping B.

summary: Union $\cup$: Combine all elements.
Intersection $\cap$: Common elements only.
Difference $A-B$: Remove B's elements from A.

quickCheckQuestions.question: Is union commutative ($A \cup B = B \cup A$)?

content.title: Union, Intersection, and Difference
content.description: Visualizing and calculating set operations.

content.title: Calculating Sets
content.description: Perform operations on given sets.

questions.question: If $A = \{2, 4\}$ and $B = \{2, 4, 6\}$, find $A \cap B$.
questions.explanation: Intersection takes common elements. 2 and 4 are in both.

questions.question: $A - B$ is always equal to $B - A$.
questions.explanation: Difference is not commutative. {1,2} - {2} = {1}, but {2} - {1,2} = φ.

content.title: Combined Operations
content.description: Solve multi-step set problems.

questions.question: Let $A=\{1, 2, 3\}, B=\{3, 4, 5\}, C=\{4, 5, 6\}$. Find $(A \cup B) \cap C$.
questions.explanation: $A \cup B = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5\}$. Intersecting this with $C=\{4, 5, 6\}$ gives common elements $\{4, 5\}$.

questions.question: What is $(A \cap B) \cup (A - B)$?
questions.explanation: $A \cap B$ is the part of A inside B. $A - B$ is the part of A outside B. Putting them together reconstructs A.

sections.title: Complement of a Set
sections.description: Explains the set of elements in the universal set that are not in a specific set.

content.introduction: The complement of a set represents everything that is NOT in the set, within the context of the Universal Set.

coreConcepts.explanation: Let $U$ be the universal set and $A$ a subset of $U$. The complement of $A$, denoted $A'$ or $A^c$, is the set of all elements of $U$ which are not in $A$. Formula: $A' = U - A$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A rectangle U with a circle A. The region inside U but outside A is shaded.

coreConcepts.explanation:
Two important laws relate operations and complements: 
1. $(A \cup B)' = A' \cap B'$ 
2. $(A \cap B)' = A' \cup B'$ 
The complement of the union is the intersection of complements, and vice versa.
coreConcepts.example: Think of 'Not (A or B)' as 'Not A and Not B'.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Side-by-side Venn diagrams verifying the first De Morgan Law.

summary: $A'$ contains elements in U but not A.
De Morgan's Laws link Union/Intersection with Complement.

quickCheckQuestions.question: What is the complement of the Universal Set?

content.title: Understanding Complements
content.description: Visualizing complements and proving De Morgan's Laws.

content.title: Finding what's missing
content.description: Calculate complements and apply laws.

questions.question: If $U = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5\}$ and $A = \{1, 5\}$, find $A'$.
questions.explanation: Remove 1 and 5 from U. Remaining are {2, 3, 4}.

questions.question: $(A \cup B)' = A' \cup B'$
questions.explanation: This is false. De Morgan's Law states $(A \cup B)' = A' \cap B'$ (intersection, not union).

content.title: Applying Laws
content.description: Verify laws with specific sets.

questions.question: Let $U = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$, $A = \{2, 3\}$, $B = \{3, 4, 5\}$. Find $(A \cup B)'$.
questions.explanation: $A \cup B = \{2, 3, 4, 5\}$. The complement in U is $\{1, 6\}$.

questions.question: If $A \subset U$, what is $A \cup A'$?
questions.explanation: Combining a set with everything not in the set (but in U) gives the entire Universal Set.

sections.title: Practical Problems on Union and Intersection of Two Sets
sections.description: Applies set theory formulas to solve real-world word problems.

content.introduction: Set theory is not just abstract; it's a powerful tool for analyzing surveys and overlapping categories.

coreConcepts.explanation: For any two finite sets A and B: $n(A \cup B) = n(A) + n(B) - n(A \cap B)$. This is known as the Principle of Inclusion-Exclusion. We subtract the intersection because adding $n(A)$ and $n(B)$ counts the common elements twice.
coreConcepts.example: If 10 people like Tea, 8 like Coffee, and 3 like both: Total people = $10 + 8 - 3 = 15$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Venn diagram with numbers in regions, showing how the intersection is part of both circles.

coreConcepts.explanation: For three sets A, B, C: $n(A \cup B \cup C) = n(A) + n(B) + n(C) - n(A \cap B) - n(B \cap C) - n(A \cap C) + n(A \cap B \cap C)$.
coreConcepts.example: Used in complex surveys involving three options.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Three overlapping circles labeled A, B, C.

summary: Use $n(A \cup B) = n(A) + n(B) - n(A \cap B)$ for two sets.
Translate 'OR' to Union and 'AND' to Intersection.
Venn diagrams help visualize the numbers.

quickCheckQuestions.question: If sets are disjoint, what is n(A ∪ B)?

content.title: Set Theory Word Problems
content.description: Walkthrough of solving survey problems using Venn diagrams and formulas.

content.title: Real World Sets
content.description: Solve basic application problems.

questions.question: In a group of 20 people, 12 like apples and 10 like bananas. If everyone likes at least one, how many like both?
If X and Y are two sets such that X has 40 elements, X ∪ Y has 60 elements and X ∩ Y has 10 elements, how many elements does Y have?

content.title: Complex Scenarios
content.description: Solve harder survey questions.

questions.question: In a class of 35 students, 24 like Cricket and 16 like Football. Also, each student likes at least one of the two games. How many students like both Cricket and Football?
In a survey of 400 students, 100 were listed as taking Apple juice, 150 as taking Orange juice and 75 were listed as taking both. How many students were taking neither Apple nor Orange juice?
questions.explanation: First find $n(A \cup O) = 100 + 150 - 75 = 175$. This is the number taking at least one. The number taking neither is Total - Union = $400 - 175 = 225$.

chapterDescription: Explore how sets interact through Cartesian products and how these interactions form the basis for defining relations and functions, which are fundamental to mathematical modeling.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.description: An overview of connecting elements between two sets, setting the stage for relations and functions.

content.introduction: In mathematics, we often look for patterns and connections between different collections of objects. Just as we can link a capital city to its country or a student to their ID number, we can link elements of one mathematical set to another. This section introduces the foundational logic required to understand Relations and Functions.

coreConcepts.explanation: The fundamental idea behind relations is the ability to pair an object from one group with an object from another group. If we have set A and set B, we are interested in rules or associations that link $a \in A$ to $b \in B$.
coreConcepts.example: Let $A$ be a set of students and $B$ be a set of grades. We can link specific students to the grades they achieved.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A visual mapping diagram showing arrows pointing from elements in Set A to elements in Set B.

coreConcepts.explanation: To proceed, we must recall that a **Set** is a well-defined collection of objects. We denote sets with capital letters (e.g., $A, B$) and elements with lowercase letters. The symbol $\in$ means 'belongs to'.
coreConcepts.example: If $A = \{1, 2, 3\}$, then $2 \in A$ is a true statement.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A Venn diagram representing a simple set containing three numbers.

summary: Relations and functions are built upon the concept of linking elements between two non-empty sets.
A solid understanding of basic set notation ($A$, $\in$, $\subset$) is required.

quickCheckQuestions.question: What symbol is used to denote that an element belongs to a set?

microsections.title: Introduction to Relations: The Mapping Game

content.title: Introduction to Relations: The Mapping Game
content.description: A conceptual overview of how we map inputs to outputs in real-world scenarios before applying mathematical rigor.

content.title: Introduction Quiz
content.description: Test your recall of basic set theory and mapping concepts.

questions.question: If set $A = \{1, 2, 3\}$ and set $B = \{4, 5\}$, are these sets considered empty?
questions.explanation: Both sets contain elements, so they are non-empty sets.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the prerequisite for defining a relation?
questions.explanation: To link elements, we generally require two non-empty sets (though relations can exist on empty sets, the standard study involves non-empty sets).

questions.question: In the context of relations, what are we primarily trying to do?
options: Establish a link between elements of two sets
questions.explanation: The core concept is establishing a link or association between elements.

content.title: Introductory Practice
content.description: Simple exercises to identify sets and elements.

questions.question: Given $A = \{x, y, z\}$, identify the correct statement.
questions.explanation: $y$ is clearly listed as an element of $A$. Note that $z \subset A$ is incorrect notation; it should be $\{z\} \subset A$ or $z \in A$.

questions.question: If we map Countries to Capitals, and $A = \{France, Japan\}$, $B = \{Tokyo, Paris\}$, what is the correct pairing for Japan?
questions.explanation: Based on real-world facts, the capital of Japan is Tokyo.

sections.title: Cartesian Product of Sets
sections.description: Learn how to form and analyze the set of all possible ordered pairs from two non-empty sets.

content.introduction: Before we can define specific relations, we need a 'universal set' of all possible connections between two sets. This is called the Cartesian Product. It generates ordered pairs, where the order of elements matters strictly.

coreConcepts.explanation: An ordered pair consists of two elements listed in a specific order, denoted $(a, b)$. Two ordered pairs $(x, y)$ and $(a, b)$ are equal if and only if their corresponding elements are equal. That is, $(x, y) = (a, b) \iff x = a \text{ and } y = b$.
coreConcepts.example: If $(x+1, y-2) = (3, 1)$, then $x+1=3 \Rightarrow x=2$ and $y-2=1 \Rightarrow y=3$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A comparison showing $(1,2) \neq (2,1)$ on a coordinate plane.

coreConcepts.explanation: Given two non-empty sets $P$ and $Q$, the Cartesian product $P \times Q$ is the set of all ordered pairs of elements from $P$ and $Q$. Mathematically: $P \times Q = \{ (p, q) : p \in P, q \in Q \}$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A grid or matrix showing the combination of elements from Set A (rows) and Set B (columns).

coreConcepts.explanation: If $n(A) = p$ and $n(B) = q$, then the number of elements in the Cartesian product is $n(A \times B) = pq$. If either set is infinite, the product is infinite.
coreConcepts.example: If set A has 3 elements and set B has 4 elements, $A \times B$ has $3 \times 4 = 12$ elements.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: None

summary: An ordered pair $(a,b)$ is distinct from $(b,a)$ unless $a=b$.
$A \times B$ represents all possible pairings between set A and set B.
The number of elements in $A \times B$ is the product of the number of elements in A and B.

content.title: Visualizing Cartesian Products
content.description: Visualizing the cross product of sets using coordinate geometry and tree diagrams.

content.title: Cartesian Product Quiz
content.description: Assess your understanding of ordered pairs and set products.

questions.question: If $n(A) = 5$ and $n(B) = 3$, what is $n(A \times B)$?
questions.explanation: $n(A \times B) = n(A) \cdot n(B) = 5 \cdot 3 = 15$.

questions.question: Is the operation of Cartesian product commutative? i.e., is $A \times B = B \times A$ always true?
questions.explanation: No, because order matters. $(a, b) \neq (b, a)$ unless $a=b$. Thus $A \times B \neq B \times A$ unless $A=B$.

questions.question: If $(x, y) = (2, 5)$, what is the value of $x$?
questions.explanation: In ordered pairs, corresponding elements are equal. $x$ is the first component, so $x=2$.

content.title: Cartesian Product Practice
content.description: Solve problems involving ordered pairs and set construction.

questions.question: Given $(a/3 + 1, b - 2/3) = (5/3, 1/3)$, find the values of $a$ and $b$.
questions.explanation: Equate components: $\frac{a}{3} + 1 = \frac{5}{3} \Rightarrow \frac{a}{3} = \frac{2}{3} \Rightarrow a=2$. Also, $b - \frac{2}{3} = \frac{1}{3} \Rightarrow b = 1$.

questions.question: If $A = \{1, 2\}$, form the set $A \times A \times A$. How many elements does it have?
questions.explanation: $n(A \times A \times A) = 2 \times 2 \times 2 = 8$. The elements are triplets like $(1,1,1), (1,1,2)$, etc.

sections.title: Relations
sections.description: Understand relations as subsets of Cartesian products that describe a specific relationship between the first and second elements of ordered pairs.

content.introduction: While the Cartesian product contains *all* possible pairs, a **Relation** is usually a specific selection of those pairs based on a rule or relationship (e.g., 'is less than', 'is the square of').

coreConcepts.explanation: A relation $R$ from a non-empty set $A$ to a non-empty set $B$ is a subset of the Cartesian product $A \times B$. The subset is derived by describing a relationship between the first element $x$ and the second element $y$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: A Venn diagram showing Set R contained completely within Set A x B.

coreConcepts.explanation:
For a relation $R$ from $A$ to $B$:
1. **Domain**: The set of all first elements of the ordered pairs in $R$.
2. **Range**: The set of all second elements of the ordered pairs in $R$.
3. **Codomain**: The entire set $B$.
Note: $\text{Range} \subseteq \text{Codomain}$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: An arrow diagram highlighting the active inputs (domain) and active outputs (range) versus the total possible outputs (codomain).

coreConcepts.explanation: Relations can be represented algebraically via **Roster form** (listing pairs) or **Set-builder form** (defining the rule). Visually, they are represented using **Arrow diagrams**.
coreConcepts.example: Set-builder: $R = \{(x, y) : x \in A, y = x^2\}$. Roster: $R = \{(2, 4), (3, 9)\}$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Side-by-side comparison of a list of pairs and an arrow diagram.

summary: A relation is a subset of $A \times B$.
The domain is the set of inputs (first elements); the range is the set of outputs (second elements).
The range is always a subset of the codomain (Set B).

quickCheckQuestions.question: If $R = \{(1, a), (2, b)\}$, what is the Domain?

content.title: Understanding Relations and Arrow Diagrams
content.description: How to visualize relations using arrow diagrams and identify domain/range.

content.title: Relations Quiz
content.description: Test your ability to identify domains, ranges, and valid relations.

questions.question: If $A$ has $p$ elements and $B$ has $q$ elements, what is the total number of possible relations from $A$ to $B$?
questions.explanation: The number of relations is the number of subsets of $A \times B$. Since $n(A \times B) = pq$, the number of subsets is $2^{pq}$.

questions.question: In a relation $R$ from $A$ to $B$, the Range is always equal to the Codomain.
questions.explanation: The Range is a *subset* of the Codomain. It may or may not be equal to it.

questions.question: Given $R = \{(1, 3), (2, 4), (2, 5)\}$. Is this a valid relation?
questions.explanation: Yes, a relation can map a single input (2) to multiple outputs (4 and 5). This is valid for a relation (though not for a function).

content.title: Relations Practice Problems
content.description: Apply definitions to determine properties of specific relations.

questions.question: Let $A = \{1, 2, 3, ... 14\}$. Define a relation $R$ from $A$ to $A$ by $R = \{(x, y) : 3x - y = 0, \text{ where } x, y \in A\}$. Write down the Range.
Identify the Domain of the relation $R = \{(x, x+5) : x \in \{0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5\}\}$.
questions.explanation: Since the rule $x+5$ is valid for all $x$ in the given set, the domain is the entire set $\{0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5\}$.

sections.title: Functions
sections.description: Study functions as a special type of relation where every element of the first set has one and only one image in the second set.

content.introduction: A function is the most important concept in calculus and modern mathematics. It is a stricter version of a relation, often described as a machine that takes an input and produces exactly one output.

coreConcepts.explanation: A relation $f$ from a set $A$ to a set $B$ is said to be a function if every element of set $A$ has one and **only one** image in set $B$. If $f$ is a function from $A$ to $B$ and $(a, b) \in f$, then $f(a) = b$, where $b$ is the image of $a$.
coreConcepts.example: $f(x) = x^2$ is a function because every real number squared yields a unique result. $y^2 = x$ is not a function because if $x=4$, $y$ could be $2$ or $-2$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Diagram showing 'One-to-One' and 'Many-to-One' mappings (Functions) vs 'One-to-Many' (Not a Function).

coreConcepts.explanation: A function which has either $\mathbb{R}$ (the set of real numbers) or one of its subsets as its range is called a real-valued function. If its domain is also $\mathbb{R}$ or a subset, it is called a real function.
coreConcepts.example: $f(x) = \sqrt{x}$ is a real function defined for $x \ge 0$.
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: Graph of a standard curve on Cartesian coordinates.

coreConcepts.explanation:
For functions $f: X \to \mathbb{R}$ and $g: X \to \mathbb{R}$, we can define:
1. Sum: $(f+g)(x) = f(x) + g(x)$
2. Difference: $(f-g)(x) = f(x) - g(x)$
3. Product: $(fg)(x) = f(x)g(x)$
4. Quotient: $(\frac{f}{g})(x) = \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}, g(x) \neq 0$
coreConcepts.diagramDescription: None

summary: Every input in a function must have exactly one output.
The Vertical Line Test helps identify functions graphically.
We can perform arithmetic operations on functions just like numbers.

quickCheckQuestions.question: Is the relation $\{(1,2), (1,3)\}$ a function?
quickCheckQuestions.answer: No, because the input 1 has two different outputs.

microsections.title: Is it a Function? The Vertical Line Test

content.title: Is it a Function? The Vertical Line Test
content.description: Using graphs to determine if a relation is a function, and calculating domains of common functions.

content.title: Functions Quiz
content.description: Distinguish between relations and functions and perform basic function algebra.

questions.question: Which of the following arrow diagrams represents a function?
options: One element in Domain maps to two elements in Codomain
An element in Domain has no image
Every element in Domain maps to a unique element in Codomain
Two elements in Domain map to different elements, but one is undefined
questions.explanation: By definition, every element in the domain must map to exactly one image.

questions.question: If $f(x) = x^2$ and $g(x) = x$, what is $(f \cdot g)(2)$?
A circle graphed on the Cartesian plane represents a function of $y$ in terms of $x$.
questions.explanation: A circle fails the Vertical Line Test. For a given $x$, there are usually two $y$ values (positive and negative).

content.title: Function Analysis Practice
content.description: Determine domains and ranges of real functions.

questions.question: Find the domain of the real function $f(x) = \frac{x^2 + 2x + 1}{x^2 - 8x + 12}$.
questions.explanation: The function is undefined when the denominator is zero. $x^2 - 8x + 12 = 0 \Rightarrow (x-6)(x-2) = 0$. So $x=6$ or $x=2$. Domain is all reals except these two points.

questions.question: Find the domain and range of $f(x) = \sqrt{x-1}$.
questions.explanation: For the root to be real, $x-1 \ge 0 \Rightarrow x \ge 1$. Thus Domain is $[1, \infty)$. The output of a square root is non-negative, so Range is $[0, \infty)$.
